data.title: About Us
data.detail: Marpha Public School was established in the year 1990 in Kathmandu with 100 students and 20 staff members. In the year 2001 with the vision of providing quality education at an affordable cost by using modern pedagogies in the state-of-the art infrastructure facilities it shifted to its own property of around 20 ropanis land in Thapathali, Kathmandu which is in heart of the city. It has modern academic buildings with spacious classrooms, laboratories, Activity hall, separate boys and girls hostel buildings, administrative building, dining hall equipped with modern kitchen facilities.

data.title: Vision and Mission
data.detail: Our motto “HONESTY & LOYALTY” reflects our understanding and beliefs. With Honesty and Loyalty deeply embedded in our heart we encourage innovative learning through our academic and non-academic programs. Marpha cultivates excellence in every student by engaging them in rigorous and relevant learning opportunities that promote academic, physical, social and emotional growth.

data.title: Learning Principles
data.detail: At the center of Marpha Pedagogy are students with their own learning styles, strengths and challenges. Students come to school with combinations of unique and shared patterns of values, knowledge and experience of the world and their place in it. Promoting open communication based on understanding and respect, Marpha encourages students to become active, compassionate lifelong learners. Marpha Pedagogy is holistic in nature - it’s concerned with the development, Marpha pedagogy addresses students’ social, emotional and physical well-being. The learners’ need is the pedagogy’s mission of the future. It requires learners to attempt to become inquirers, researchers, inquisitive, speakers, righteous, modern, caring, courageous, independent, balanced and thoughtful. These attributes the learners represent, are internationally accepted a broad range of human capacities and responsibilities that go beyond a concern for intellectual development and academic content. They involve a pledge to implement principles and values that support all members of the school community learn to respect themselves, others and the world around them.

songs.title: School Song
songs.detail: My Mummy says I'm a miracle! My Daddy says I'm his special little guy! I am a Princess

songs.title: National Anthem
songs.detail: sayaun thungaa phoolka haami eutai maalaa Nepali

details.rule: Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry.
To respect the rights of others to learn.
To respect their peers and teachers regardless of ethnicity, religion or gender
To respect the property and equipment of the school and others
To carry out reasonable instructions to the best of their ability

School Uniform should be worn tidily and correctly both at school and between home and school. The full school uniform must be worn at all times. Shirts are to be tucked in; socks are to be pulled up; heel straps in place. Where a situation arises concerning a student’s uniform, written requests for the temporary wearing of non-regulation items must be referred to a Dean or Senior Leadership.
Students are to be clean-shaven at all times while representing the school.

No jewellery, except a watch, is to be worn. Jewellery of religious or cultural significance may be worn but must be covered at all times. No piercings are allowed. In particular, clear plastic studs, or otherwise, used to maintain the piercing, are not allowed.

A student’s hair must be kept clean and tidy at all times. The length of the hair should not be shorter than a “number 2” razor cut. Hair should not be touching the shirt collar and should be off the face at all times. The style of the hair should not be extreme, including but not limited to mohawk, afro, shaved styles and/or patterns, hair tied up and braided. The colour must be the student’s own natural colour; no dye nor highlights are allowed.
Students are not permitted to have visible tattoos.
